awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A New Yeast Biomanufacturing Platform for Making High-value Products from Oils and Fats
awd_abstract_narration:
The United States produces more than 20 million tons of plant oils and animal fats every year. Used for food and feed applications, they generate low or limited economic value. The plant oils and fats wasted during food production negatively impact the environment. This project aims to develop a yeast to convert oils and fats into a series of high-value products. These products might include omega-3 fatty acids, carotenoids, and wax esters. If successful, this project could use yeast to create products that improve human health with minimal environmental impact. High school teachers will be trained in the lab, as will undergraduates and graduate students.  Current outreach activities to the Texas School for the Deaf and a local K-5 elementary school will be augmented, as will efforts to recruit underrepresented minorities and women to pursue STEM training. Overall, the project will support the development of a workforce prepared for leadership in the growing bioeconomy industry.

The oleaginous yeast Yarrowia lipolytica will be metabolically engineered to convert oils and fats into high-value products. Both cellular engineering and bioreaction engineering research will be integrated in this project to establish this biomanufacturing platform. First, the yeast will be engineered both metabolically and physiologically to facilitate the uptake of extracellular substrate and the bioconvesion of intracellular fatty acids. Second, the uptake of fatty acid substrates will be enhanced through modifying cellular transporters. Third, biosynthesis pathways will be created and optimized to convert the intracellular fatty acids into omega-3 fatty acids, wax esters, carotenoids, and other products. Forth, on the bioprocess side, mass transfer limitations of extracellular oils/fats/fatty acids in a bioreactor caused by the insolubility of the hydrophobic substrates in aqueous medium will be reduced through the use of a multi-phase (gas, oil, aqueous) computational fluid dynamics (CFD) model. Ultimately, a general bioreactor model will be built to describe processes for both extracellular mass transfer of oils/fats and the intracellular bioconversion of fatty acids into each specific high-value product.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report 

Collaborative Research: A New Yeast Biomanufacturing Platform for Making High-value Products from Oils and Fats

NSF/CBET (Award Number 1911480, Project Period 04/01/2020 ~ 12/31/2024)

PI: Dongming Xie, Dept. of Chemical Engineering, University of Massachusetts Lowell

Co-PI: Seongkyu Yoon, Dept. of Chemical Engineering, University of Massachusetts Lowell

 

Project Goal

To significantly increase the values of plant oils and animal fats and expand their applications, this project aims to establish a new biomanufacturing platform that uses a metabolically engineered yeast, Yarrowia lipolytica, to directly convert oils/fats into a series of high-value products such as omega-3 fatty acids, wax esters, carotenoids,  and long-chain diacids. This project mainly focuses on two high-value products from oils/fats: wax esters and omega-3 EPA (C20:5).

Objective #1: Establishing a new yeast platform

  • 1.1 Identifying a Y. lipolytica strain as the research platform. 
  • 1.2 Cell morphology engineering of Y. lipolytica.
  • 1.3 Cellular engineering to maximize oil uptake capacity.   
  • 1.4 Metabolic engineering for high-value products from oils/fats:

Objective #2: Develop a novel bioreactor system for oil/fat bioconversion

  • 2.1 CFD modelling and simulation for bioreactors with oil medium.
  • 2.2 Bioreaction model for oil uptake and bioconversion. 
  • 2.3 Experimental validation of the bioreactor model.

 

Summary of major achievements:

 1.     Technical Achievements:

(1)   A Y. lipolytica yeast strain able to produce 56% wax esters in biomass from oils/fats, which reports the highest wax ester level so far.

(2)   An E. coli strain able to produce ~10% wax esters in biomass from oils/fats, which reports the highest wax ester level by E. coli so far.

(3)   A new yeast strain and fermentation process to improve omega-3 EPA production by ~50% with waste oils/fats.

(4)   New strategies of using inducible DGA1, TGL4 mutations, overexpression of FAA1/GPD1, fused D9-D8, D5, D12, and D15/D17 for converting free fatty acids  to omega-3 EPA in the format of triacylglycerides (TAGs).

 

2.     Journal publications:

(1)   Metabolic Engineering, 2021, 67: 428-442.

(2)   Biotechnology and Bioengineering, 2021, 118: 1658-1673.

(3)   Biotechnology Advances, 2023, 65: 108128.

(4)   Biotechnology Journal, 2024, 19: 2300384.

(5)   Frontiers in Microbiology, 2023, 14: 1280296.

(6)   Biotechnology Journal 2024, 19: e202400506.

(7)   ACS Engineering Au 2025, https://doi.org/10.1021/acsengineeringau.4c00053.

 

3.     Book chapter

(1)   Liu, N., Soong, YH.V., Olson, A., Xie, D. (2022). Cellular Engineering of Yarrowia lipolytica for Biomanufacturing of High-Value Products from Oils and Fats. In: Darvishi Harzevili, F. (eds) Synthetic Biology of Yeasts. Springer, Cham. pp63-90. 

 

4.     Patent application

(1)   D Xie, YHV Soong, LIU Na, AT Olson, HW Wong. Microbial conversion of oils and fats to lipid-derived high-value products. US Patent App. 17/341,767, 2022.

 

5.     Supported PhD graduate students

(1)   Na Liu (04/01/2020 – 11/15/2021),

(2)   Ya-Hue Valerie Soong (Apr – Aug 2020),

(3)   Richard Marx (09/01/2020-08/31/2022),

(4)   Jiansong Qin (01/01/2022-12/2024).

 

6.     Other Achievements

(1)   From Nov 2022, we are also participating in the NSF I-Corp program at UML, which is to identify industrial partners for the opportunities of commercializing wax esters and/or omega-3 fatty acids that are developed during this NSF project.

(2)   This project has also provided research opportunity for four undergraduate students, who were able to conduct research with hands on experience and become coauthors of published papers and conference presentations.

(3)   By collaborating with Massachusetts Life Science Center (MLSC), this project provides a 6-week research intern opportunity for one student in each summer (2022 & 2023). MLSC provided the funding, and this project provided a mini-research projects for students.

 

Project’s impact on institutional resources that form infrastructure

Bioengineering sub-program is growing fast in the chemical engineering department at UMass Lowell. Students have shown more and more interests in studying biomanufacturing and related knowledge due to the great number of biotechnology companies located in the Boston area. The growth of undergraduate and graduate programs and the funding from federal agency such as NSF helped the University to provide more support for our biomanufacturing programs. We have also successfully received two $750,000 capital investments from Massachusetts Life Science Center (MLSC), for the period of 2019-2021 and 2022-2024, respectively.

 

Project’s impact on society beyond science and technology

The success of the project will re-shape oils and fats from low-value, common agriculture commodities to high-value products that have critical benefits in improving human health and life quality with minimal environmental footprints. This may help significantly improve the profit of farmers growing various oil crops such as palm, soybean, and rape seed. We have demonstrated that the waste cooking oils (WCOs) can be used for biomanufacturing both wax esters and omega-3 fatty acids at extremely high yield, which may lead to commercialization opportunities. The gained new knowledge and methods in synthetic biology of yeast and bioreaction engineering can be applied to many other biomanufacturing processes.

 


Last Modified: 04/09/2025
Modified by: Dongming Xie

Project Outcomes Report


Collaborative Research: A New Yeast Biomanufacturing Platform for Making High-valueProducts from Oils and Fats


NSF/CBET (Award Number 1911480, Project Period 04/01/2020 ~ 12/31/2024)


PI: Dongming Xie, Dept. of Chemical Engineering, University of Massachusetts Lowell


Co-PI: Seongkyu Yoon, Dept. of Chemical Engineering, University of Massachusetts Lowell





Project Goal


To significantly increase the values of plant oils and animal fats and expand their applications, this project aims to establish a new biomanufacturing platform that uses a metabolically engineered yeast,Yarrowia lipolytica, to directly convert oils/fats into a series of high-value products such as omega-3 fatty acids, wax esters, carotenoids, and long-chain diacids.This project mainly focuses on two high-value products from oils/fats: wax esters and omega-3 EPA (C20:5).


Objective #1:Establishing a new yeast platform

1.1 Identifying aY. lipolyticastrain      as the research platform. 


1.2 Cell morphology engineering ofY.      lipolytica.


1.3 Cellular engineering to maximize oil uptake      capacity. 


1.4 Metabolic engineering for high-value products from      oils/fats: 



Objective #2:Develop a novel bioreactor system for oil/fat bioconversion

2.1 CFD modelling and simulation for bioreactors with      oil medium.


2.2 Bioreaction model for oil uptake and      bioconversion.


2.3 Experimental validation of the bioreactor model.






Summary of major achievements:


1. Technical Achievements:


(1) A Y. lipolytica yeast strain able to produce 56% wax esters in biomass from oils/fats, which reports the highest wax ester level so far.


(2) An E. coli strain able to produce ~10% wax esters in biomass from oils/fats, which reports the highest wax ester level by E. coli so far.


(3) A new yeast strain and fermentation process to improve omega-3 EPA production by ~50% with waste oils/fats.


(4) New strategies of using inducible DGA1, TGL4 mutations, overexpression of FAA1/GPD1, fused D9-D8, D5, D12, and D15/D17 for converting free fatty acids to omega-3 EPA in the format of triacylglycerides (TAGs).





2. Journal publications:


(1) Metabolic Engineering, 2021, 67: 428-442.


(2) Biotechnology and Bioengineering, 2021, 118: 1658-1673.


(3) Biotechnology Advances, 2023, 65: 108128.


(4) Biotechnology Journal, 2024, 19: 2300384.

(6) Biotechnology Journal 2024, 19: e202400506.


(7) ACS Engineering Au 2025, https://doi.org/10.1021/acsengineeringau.4c00053.





3. Book chapter


(1) Liu, N., Soong, YH.V., Olson, A., Xie, D. (2022). Cellular Engineering of Yarrowia lipolytica for Biomanufacturing of High-Value Products from Oils and Fats. In: Darvishi Harzevili, F. (eds) Synthetic Biology of Yeasts. Springer, Cham. pp63-90.





4. Patent application


(1) D Xie, YHV Soong, LIU Na, AT Olson, HW Wong. Microbial conversion of oils and fats to lipid-derived high-value products. US Patent App. 17/341,767, 2022.





5. Supported PhD graduate students

(1) From Nov 2022, we are also participating in the NSF I-Corp program at UML, which is to identify industrial partners for the opportunities of commercializing wax esters and/or omega-3 fatty acids that are developed during this NSF project.


(2) This project has also provided research opportunity for four undergraduate students, who were able to conduct research with hands on experience and become coauthors of published papers and conference presentations.


(3) By collaborating with Massachusetts Life Science Center (MLSC), this project provides a 6-week research intern opportunity for one student in each summer (2022 & 2023). MLSC provided the funding, and this project provided a mini-research projects for students.

Students have shown more and more interests in studying biomanufacturing and related knowledge due to the great number of biotechnology companies located in the Boston area. This may help significantly improve the profit of farmers growing various oil crops such as palm, soybean, and rape seed. We have demonstrated that the waste cooking oils (WCOs) can be used for biomanufacturing both wax esters and omega-3 fatty acids at extremely high yield, which may lead to commercialization opportunities. The gained new knowledge and methods in synthetic biology of yeast and bioreaction engineering can be applied to many other biomanufacturing processes.
